Yes, here are some examples of specific projects or initiatives that the Royal Geographical Society (RGS) has undertaken that highlight their use of new technologies:

1. Crowd-sourced Mapping: In 2010, the RGS initiated a crowd-sourced mapping project called "The Great Map," which aimed to create a comprehensive map of the UK using data collected from members of the public using their smartphones. The project used GPS technology to pinpoint exact locations and allowed users to provide detailed information about the places they visited, including photographs and descriptions. The result was the creation of a detailed and up-to-date map that was freely available to the public.

2. GIS-based Mapping: The RGS has worked on a number of GIS-based mapping projects, including the creation of a digital atlas of African history and culture. The project, called "Mapping Africa's Endangered Cultural Heritage," used GIS technology to map cultural sites and artifacts across Africa and to assess their condition and vulnerability to damage or destruction.

3. Remote Sensing and Satellite Imagery: The RGS has been involved in several projects that use remote sensing and satellite imagery to study the Earth's surface. For example, the RGS partnered with the European Space Agency (ESA) to develop a program that uses satellite data to monitor deforestation and land use change in the Amazon rainforest.

4. Geographic Information Systems (GIS): In recent years, the RGS has worked on several GIS-based projects, including the creation of a new digital archive of maps, expeditions, and other geographic data. The archive uses GIS technology to allow users to group and search data by theme, location, or time period, making it easier to explore and analyze large amounts of data.

Overall, the Royal Geographical Society has been at the forefront of using new technologies to advance geographic knowledge, and it continues to seek out innovative new tools and techniques for studying the world around us.
